results.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Trump Halts U.S. Funding of World Health Organization
results.abstract: New York deaths spike as the state releases a revised count, and California explores steps toward reopening. The Treasury Department says it has reached a deal on an airline bailout.

results.title: Trump’s Claim of Total Authority in Crisis Is Rejected Across Ideological Lines
results.abstract: Trading barbs with governors about their powers over when to ease restrictions on society, the president made an assertion that lacks a basis in the Constitution or federal law.

multimedia.caption: Even some supporters of the most sweeping view of presidential emergency powers deemed President Trump’s assertion to be empty.

results.title: U.S. Governors, at Center of Virus Response, Weigh What It Will Take to Reopen States
results.abstract: Many governors say science will guide when they will allow a reopening, a choice they say belongs to them. “Normal it will not be,” Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said.

results.title: Stay 6 Feet Apart, We’re Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
results.abstract: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the “trillion dollar question.”
results.byline: By Knvul Sheikh, James Gorman and Kenneth Chang
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: A sign on the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn advised visitors to keep a distance of at least six feet from each other, but some experts say that might not be enough.

results.title: This 3-D Simulation Shows Why Social Distancing Is So Important
results.abstract: We visualized a cough to show how far respiratory droplets can spread. If you haven’t been keeping your distance to fight the coronavirus, this may persuade you.
results.byline: By Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Bedel Saget, Karthik Patanjali, Or Fleisher and Gabriel Gianordoli

results.title: What Doctors on the Front Lines Wish They’d Known a Month Ago
results.abstract: Ironclad emergency medical practices — about when to use ventilators, for example — have dissolved almost overnight.

results.title: What Does It Mean When an Artist Retreats From Public Life?
results.abstract: A small and highly influential group has chosen to disappear from society in favor of letting their work speak for itself.

multimedia.caption: T commissioned original works by the artist Jessica Wohl, who made pieces inspired by the artists mentioned in this essay. The snowballs that blanket this family portrait are a reference to the artist DAVID HAMMONS’s ephemeral 1983 piece “Bliz-aard Ball Sale,” in which he sold snowballs on the streets of New York City. The frame is an interpretation of his “African American Flag,” which Hammons created in 1990, replacing the flag’s traditional red, white and blue with the black, red and green of Marcus Garvey’s Pan-African flag.

results.title: How to Manage Panic Attacks
results.abstract: The sudden, short-lived feeling of anxiety, shortness of breath and disabling fear can be confused with symptoms of coronavirus. Here’s what to do about it.

results.title: Cupid in Quarantine
results.abstract: A global tragedy has forced us into full-time togetherness. Here’s how couples can rekindle romantic love and grow together rather than apart.

results.title: Track Down the Mystery Person Who Just Texted You
results.abstract: “New phone, who dis?”

results.title: Why You Should Start a Coronavirus Diary
results.abstract: It’ll help you organize your thoughts during these difficult times, and may help educate future generations.

results.title: Recovered From Coronavirus? Here’s How You Can Help
results.abstract: Most important: Remember that being recovered does not make you immune from practicing good hygiene.

results.title: What Was Life Like for Sailors During the Battle of the Atlantic?
results.abstract: For those fighting the longest naval campaign of World War II, weather and German U-boats were constant threats.
results.kicker: Beyond the World War II We Know
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: A ‘Full Deck’ of Chekhov, With the Translators as the Wild Cards
results.abstract: In “Fifty-Two Stories,” translated by Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, the vigorous soul of the Russian master’s writing shines through.

results.title: Starved for Sports? Here Are 5 Options That Aren’t N.B.A. Classic
results.abstract: On the menu: trenchant documentaries from ESPN and HBO, dramas about Norwegian soccer and Korean baseball, and an addictive exploration of pro wrestling.

results.abstract: Publishers and nonprofits are finding ways to get books and information to housebound children worldwide.

results.abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

results.title: Computers Already Learn From Us. But Can They Teach Themselves?
results.abstract: Scientists are exploring approaches that would help machines develop their own sort of common sense.

results.title: Putin’s Long War Against American Science
results.abstract: A decade of health disinformation promoted by President Vladimir Putin of Russia has sown wide confusion, hurt major institutions and encouraged the spread of deadly illnesses.

results.title: Small Chloroquine Study Halted Over Risk of Fatal Heart Complications
results.abstract: A research trial of coronavirus patients in Brazil ended after patients taking a higher dose of chloroquine, one of the drugs President Trump has promoted, developed irregular heart rates.
results.byline: By Katie Thomas and Knvul Sheikh
